drills.name: Resistance Band Pull – Face to Neck Anchors
General Isometric Holds (5-position circuit)
drills.notes: Engage large muscle groups without load; avoid pain. Hold 15–30s x 3 rounds.

drills.name: Foam Rolling + Tempo Eccentrics
drills.notes: Roll full body + slow eccentrics to recondition tissue under control.

drills.name: Joint Stability Circuit (ankle, knee, wrist)
drills.notes: Use bands, BOSU, or unstable surfaces. Controlled tempo x 3 sets.

drills.name: Isometric Joint Compression Holds
drills.notes: Mid-range holds for joint stiffness without movement. Build neuromuscular confidence.

drills.name: Global Mobility Flow (Full Body)
drills.notes: 12–15 mins of dynamic stretching, PNF holds, and breath-led movement.

drills.name: Contrast Showers + Deep Tissue Tooling
drills.notes: 1 min hot / 1 min cold x5 + lacrosse ball on most restricted areas.

drills.name: Recovery Circuit (Airdyne, Row, Band Mobility)
drills.notes: Low RPE movement with mobility and breath pacing. 3–4 rounds.

drills.name: Epsom Salt Bath + Active ROM Post-Soak
drills.notes: 20 mins hot soak + unloaded movement to promote circulation and recovery.

drills.name: Isometric Pain-Free Loading (Top/Bottom Range)
drills.notes: Isometric tension at pain-free end ranges, hold 30s. 3–4 sets daily.

drills.name: Slow Tempo Eccentrics on Major Lifts
drills.notes: 3–4s lowering phase. Reinforces tendon capacity. Start unloaded.

drills.name: Breathwork + Parasympathetic Ground Flow
drills.notes: Releases tension. 4s inhale / 8s exhale, paired with gentle mobility.

drills.name: Neuro-Friendly Band Activation
drills.notes: Band retraction, extension, rotation drills. 3 sets light resistance.

drills.name: Loaded CARs (Controlled Articular Rotations)
drills.notes: Strengthen joint control. 3 reps per direction, per joint.

drills.name: Breath-Guided Dynamic Stretch Flow
drills.notes: Mobility tied to exhale. Repeat sequence x3 rounds full body.

drills.name: Active Range Isometrics (Antagonist Focus)
drills.notes: Contract opposing muscles near end range to protect joint integrity.

drills.name: Proprioceptive Loading on Sliders or Bands
drills.notes: Adds joint awareness while avoiding terminal ROM.

drills.name: Global Foam Roll + PNF Stretch (target problem area)
drills.notes: Start with 60–90s foam roll across main tension zones, then add 3x15s PNF contract-relax sets.

drills.name: Full-Body Mobility Circuit
drills.notes: Include inchworms, world’s greatest stretch, deep lunge opens. 2–3 rounds.

drills.name: Global Foam Roll + PNF Stretch (target problem area)
drills.notes: progress to dynamic end-range mobility drills (e.g. CARS, banded openers).

drills.name: Full-Body Mobility Circuit
drills.notes: add mild loaded mobility (e.g. goblet squat hold, elevated Cossack stretch).

drills.name: Isometric Holds (target tendon path)
drills.notes: 5x45s holds at mid-range (e.g. Spanish squat, wall sit, mid-dip hold) depending on limb.

drills.name: Banded Flossing + Elevation
drills.notes: Wrap a light compression band around joint/muscle belly, move through ROM for 30s bouts.

drills.name: Isometric Holds (target tendon path)
drills.notes: progress to slow eccentrics (e.g. heel drops, tempo pushups).

drills.name: Banded Flossing + Elevation
drills.notes: drop band, add slow ROM + high bloodflow pump work.

drills.name: Isometric Stability Holds on Unstable Surface
drills.notes: Hold split stance, tall plank, or single leg positions on foam pad or BOSU. 3x20–30s.

drills.name: Banded Stability Reps
drills.notes: Use bands to pull joint into slight instability during slow reps (e.g. banded wall squats).

drills.name: Isometric Stability Holds on Unstable Surface
drills.notes: Add light perturbation (e.g. partner taps, ball tosses).

drills.name: Banded Stability Reps
drills.notes: progress to reactive reps or light load with control.

drills.name: Heavy Slow Resistance Protocol
drills.notes: 3x8–10 slow tempo reps (e.g. 3-0-3) for target tendon line. Emphasize full control.

drills.name: Contrast Therapy + Active ROM
drills.notes: Ice/heat alternated 3–5x per area, then slow joint circles or band ROM drills.

drills.name: Heavy Slow Resistance Protocol
drills.notes: shift to sport-mimicking movement patterns under tempo.

drills.name: Contrast Therapy + Active ROM
drills.notes: remove passive input, use self-mobilizing drills only.

drills.name: Active Range Expansion with Isometrics
drills.notes: Contract-relax against resistance (e.g. doorway press, glute bridge hold). 3x20s.

drills.name: Loaded Mobility Toolwork
drills.notes: Massage gun or lacrosse ball across the stuck tissue pre-movement.

drills.name: Active Range Expansion with Isometrics
drills.notes: build into controlled eccentrics or flowing mobility reps.

drills.name: Loaded Mobility Toolwork
drills.notes: replace with movement-based mobility under low load.

drills.name: Elevation + Compression (10–15 min post)
drills.notes: Advise athlete to elevate the area above heart and wrap with compression sleeve.

drills.name: Low Tension Mobility & Lymph Flow
drills.notes: Air squats, light swings, or open chain movement to keep blood moving without stress.

drills.name: Elevation + Compression (10–15 min post)
drills.notes: remove if bruising fades, switch to pump/flush circuits.

drills.name: Low Tension Mobility & Lymph Flow
drills.notes: increase ROM and tempo gradually as pain subsides.

drills.name: Joint-Specific Controlled Eccentrics
drills.notes: Apply slow lowering to regain ROM (e.g. leg lowers, tempo dips, etc). 3x6 reps.

drills.name: Wrap Support + ROM Reset
drills.notes: Use elastic wrap during movement if needed. Add unloaded full-ROM circles pre-training.

drills.name: Joint-Specific Controlled Eccentrics
drills.notes: layer in anti-extension isometrics (e.g. plank drag).

drills.name: Wrap Support + ROM Reset
drills.notes: taper wrap use unless re-aggravation risk is present.

drills.name: Light Aerobic Flow + Stretch
drills.notes: 5–10 mins of cyclical movement (e.g. bike, jog) into a 3-round mobility flow.

drills.name: Epsom Salt Soak or Contrast Shower
drills.notes: Passive recovery aid to flush DOMS. 15–20 mins soak or 5 cycles of hot/cold shower.

drills.name: Light Aerobic Flow + Stretch
drills.notes: taper flow to 1–2 rounds and reduce aerobic duration if recovery improves.

drills.name: Epsom Salt Soak or Contrast Shower
drills.notes: reserve for high soreness or poor sleep.

drills.name: Breath-Guided Joint Mobilization
drills.notes: Focus on 3–4 joint circles or controlled articulations paired with slow nasal breathing.

drills.name: Elevate + Wrap Protocol
drills.notes: Advise light compression wrap and elevation above heart for 10–15 min post-training.

drills.name: Breath-Guided Joint Mobilization
drills.notes: convert to low-load tempo exercises for the affected region.

drills.name: Elevate + Wrap Protocol
drills.notes: if pain subsides, begin reintroducing low RPE movement.

drills.name: Soft Tissue Flushing (Foam Roller or Ball)
drills.notes: Target surrounding areas without pressing directly on the bruise. Aids lymphatic drainage.

drills.name: Elevated Leg or Arm Pulses
drills.notes: Lie down and elevate the bruised limb. Perform light flexion/extension to improve circulation and reduce pooling.

drills.name: Compression Wrap with Mobility Flow
drills.notes: Apply compression bandage, then perform gentle mobility drills to reduce swelling without provoking flare-up.

drills.name: Limb Elevation + Isometric Squeeze
drills.notes: Elevate the limb above heart level. Perform light squeezes or quad/glute sets to stimulate fluid return.

drills.name: Slow Eccentric Resistance with Band
drills.notes: Controlled lengthening under band tension to stimulate tendon healing without overload.

drills.name: Isometric Holds at Pain-Free Angle
drills.notes: Hold static contractions near the range of irritation to reinforce tendon capacity and reduce pain sensitivity.

drills.name: Controlled Joint CARs (Controlled Articular Rotations)
drills.notes: Move through safe ranges under tension. Avoid painful arcs, build capsule space.

drills.name: Banded Joint Distraction (Light Tension)
drills.notes: Use light band tension to open joint space while moving through low-load range of motion.

drills.name: Reactive Stability Drills (Eyes Closed or Band Perturbation)
drills.notes: Use bands or unstable surfaces to challenge joint control and proprioception under minimal load.

drills.name: Isometric Holds with Joint Alignment Cueing
drills.notes: Reinforce motor control and safe joint positions through static holds in vulnerable ranges.

drills.name: Active Mobility Circuits (Full Body or Region-Specific)
drills.notes: Mobilize through dynamic movement. Emphasize rhythmic motion, not static stretching.

drills.name: Heat-then-Move Protocol (e.g., Hot Pack + Flow)
drills.notes: Apply localized heat for 10 min, then transition into controlled movement or CARs to expand usable range.

drills.name: Joint Guarding Isometrics
drills.notes: Hold positions just short of lockout to train tissue safety and reinforce control at terminal ranges.

drills.name: Partial ROM Strength Drills (Reverse Range)
drills.notes: Train in shortened range away from end-range stretch. Focus on deceleration and reverse control.

drills.name: Double-Leg Eccentric Heel Raises (3s Lower)
drills.notes: Progress to single-leg or add weight

drills.name: Towel Scrunches (Isometric Holds)
drills.notes: Maintain intrinsic foot strength without load

drills.name: Night Splint-Assisted Calf Stretch
drills.notes: Passive ROM maintenance during sleep cycles

drills.notes: 5s holds to prime neural drive pre-competition
